results.snippet: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is clamping down on the entrepreneurial spirit of Americans hoping to turn a profit on the space shuttle.    Later this year civilians will be allowed to fly aboard the shuttle. But under new...
results.lead_paragraph: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration is clamping down on the entrepreneurial spirit of Americans hoping to turn a profit on the space shuttle. Later this year civilians will be allowed to fly aboard the shuttle. But under new regulations issued by the space agency, the flights will be no boon to promotional ventures.

results.snippet: LondonCovent Garden, Madame Tussaud's    For kids under 12, I would strongly recommend the London Zoo in Regent's Park and Hamley's, probably the world's leading toy shop, 188 Regent Street. It makes F. A. O. Schwarz look like a bargain basement;...
results.lead_paragraph: LondonCovent Garden, Madame Tussaud's For kids under 12, I would strongly recommend the London Zoo in Regent's Park and Hamley's, probably the world's leading toy shop, 188 Regent Street. It makes F. A. O. Schwarz look like a bargain basement; my 11- year-old stepson considers it the promised land. For over-12's, the street scene in Covent Garden, which features buskers and dancers, and Madame Tussaud's wax museum and planetarium have proved very popular. On a more serious level, kids like the Tower of London, with Crown jewels and Beefeaters, very much. The telephone directory's Yellow Pages have a list of baby-sitting agencies. One that can be highly recommended is Universal Aunts, 250 Kings Road, London SW3 (telephone 351-5767). They will also meet children arriving alone by plane, and they conduct sightseeing tours for them, singly or in groups. For real emergencies, dial 999 and give particulars to the operator. Again, the Yellow Pages have a list of private doctors, or you may consult the hotel about National Health Service offices (as the British call the clinics) in the area.

headline.main: MANHATTAN MEETING IS THE TALK OF SCIENCE

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: SCIENCE, AMERICAN ASSOCIATION FOR THE ADVANCEMENT OF

results.snippet: FOR sheer intellectual esoterica, nothing can top the limited engagement hit that is opening in Manhattan this week. Billed as the Town Hall of Science, this production will bring together 5,000 scientists and science buffs from around the country...
results.lead_paragraph: FOR sheer intellectual esoterica, nothing can top the limited engagement hit that is opening in Manhattan this week. Billed as the Town Hall of Science, this production will bring together 5,000 scientists and science buffs from around the country for a sometimes rowdy run of discussions, arguments and occasional protests involving hundreds of subjects ranging in importance from atomic weapons to U.F.O.'s. The session that officially begins Thursday is the 150th meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, whose theme this year is ''Science, Engineering, Technology, Education: Toward a World Perspective.'' While some scientific groups will begin meeting Wednesday, the main sessions of the association open Friday and continue through next Tuesday at the New York Hilton, Avenue of the Americas at 53d Street, and the Sheraton Centre, Seventh Avenue at 52d Street, where scores of meeting rooms have been reserved for participants. Registration for the sessions will be at the Hilton.

headline.main: NEIGHBORS OF ROCKWELL ACCEPT SITE OF MUSEUM

results.snippet: Despite fears that tourists would trample the small-town life that Norman Rockwell captured on canvas in his years here, townspeople have decided to allow the building of a new museum to house the artist's works.   The paintings, willed to the...
results.lead_paragraph: Despite fears that tourists would trample the small-town life that Norman Rockwell captured on canvas in his years here, townspeople have decided to allow the building of a new museum to house the artist's works. The paintings, willed to the trustees of the museum, are now displayed in crowded circumstances in Corner House, an 18th-century building Mr. Rockwell saved from the wrecker's ball. Average attendance there has been about 100,000 visitors a year, according to the museum director, David Wood. No big increase is expected at the new facility, but it would be in a residential neighborhood, rather than on the main street, and some opponents feared a flood of visitors.

headline.kicker: COMMENCEMENTS '84: GRADUATES TOLD TO BUILD A BETTER FUTURE
headline.main: RUTGERS UNIVERSITY; BLOUSTEIN SAYS STATE SCHOOLS ARE BECOMING MORE IMPORTANT

results.snippet: State universities such as Rutgers will increasingly become more important to the country's prosperity and security, the president of Rutgers told graduates today.    State universities have evolved from serving agriculture and bolstering local...
results.lead_paragraph: State universities such as Rutgers will increasingly become more important to the country's prosperity and security, the president of Rutgers told graduates today. State universities have evolved from serving agriculture and bolstering local pride, the president, Edward J. Bloustein, said. They are increasingly undertaking research of national significance, ''with increasing amounts of their financial support coming from the national budget - public and corporate,'' he said.

headline.main: HONORARY DEGREES FOR 5,000: MOTIVES AS VARIED AS SCHOOLS

results.snippet: James E. Burke, the chairman of Johnson & Johnson, bowed his head before the 9,100 graduates of Rutgers University Thursday as the university registrar and gonfalonier placed an academic hood with a scarlet lining and white trim around his...
results.lead_paragraph: James E. Burke, the chairman of Johnson & Johnson, bowed his head before the 9,100 graduates of Rutgers University Thursday as the university registrar and gonfalonier placed an academic hood with a scarlet lining and white trim around his shoulders. The scarlet symbolizes Rutgers and the white represents arts, letters and humanities. The ritual meant Mr. Lerner possessed an honorary Doctor of Humane Letters degree for being an ''astute entrepreneur and energetic proponent of corporate civic duty.'' Mr. Burke's is one of an estimated 5,000 honorary degrees being awarded by colleges and universities around the country this commencement season, perpetuating a tradition almost as old as higher education itself. The degrees are viewed not only as a means of honoring high achievement but also of providing role models for students, publicity for the institution and encouragement of fields in which it specializes.

results.snippet: A FEMALE Vice Presidential candidate would represent a gain for the Democratic ticket, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro said last week during a visit to the county. In an interview after her speech to the Women's Bar Association of the State of...
results.lead_paragraph: A FEMALE Vice Presidential candidate would represent a gain for the Democratic ticket, Representative Geraldine A. Ferraro said last week during a visit to the county. In an interview after her speech to the Women's Bar Association of the State of New York, meeting in White Plains, the Queens Democrat, who has frequently been mentioned as a potential Vice Presidential candidate, said: ''There are a lot of voters who would vote for a woman.'' The three-term Representative said she differed with the findings of a recent New York Times/CBS News Poll that showed that a female Vice Presidential candidate on the Democratic ticket would lose as many votes as she would gain for the ticket. Mrs. Ferraro observed: ''Every other poll that I have seen shows a woman would help the ticket, and I believe those polls are accurate.'' Brushing aside questions about her own Vice Presidential aspirations, Mrs. Ferraro said, ''Either Mondale or Hart would be a super Presidential candidate'' and ''I will rely on the judgment of the eventual nominee to choose the best Vice President.''

results.snippet: What caught the eye in all the bustle of women in corsages, men in their best suits, red streamers and yellow balloons were the preschool children, filling two rows of seats in the Paterson, N.J., gym. They all wore white T-shirts bearing their own...
results.lead_paragraph: What caught the eye in all the bustle of women in corsages, men in their best suits, red streamers and yellow balloons were the preschool children, filling two rows of seats in the Paterson, N.J., gym. They all wore white T-shirts bearing their own names - Terrell, April, Seth - on the back and the same man's name on the front. ''Who do we like?'' asked Miss Ellerbee, their teacher.
